trans-unit.source: Git commands for creating a new article or updating an existing article
trans-unit.target: Git commands for creating a new article or updating an existing article

trans-unit.source: Steps for working with the Azure technical content GitHub repositories.
trans-unit.target: Steps for working with the Azure technical content GitHub repositories.

trans-unit.source: Git commands for creating a new article or updating an existing article
trans-unit.target: Git commands for creating a new article or updating an existing article

trans-unit.source: Standard process (working from master)
trans-unit.target: Standard process (working from master)

trans-unit.source: Follow the steps in this article to create a local working branch on your computer so that you can create a new article for the technical documentation section of azure.microsoft.com or update an existing article.
trans-unit.target: Follow the steps in this article to create a local working branch on your computer so that you can create a new article for the technical documentation section of azure.microsoft.com or update an existing article.

trans-unit.source: Start Git Bash (or the command-line tool you use for Git).
trans-unit.target: Start Git Bash (or the command-line tool you use for Git).

trans-unit.source: **Note:** If you are working in the public repository, change azure-content-pr to azure-content in all the commands.
trans-unit.target: **Note:** If you are working in the public repository, change azure-content-pr to azure-content in all the commands.

trans-unit.source: Change to azure-content-pr:
trans-unit.target: Change to azure-content-pr:

trans-unit.source: Check out the master branch:
trans-unit.target: Check out the master branch:

trans-unit.source: Create a fresh local working branch derived from the master branch:
trans-unit.target: Create a fresh local working branch derived from the master branch:

trans-unit.source: Move into the new working branch:
trans-unit.target: Move into the new working branch:

trans-unit.source: Let your fork know you created the local working branch:
trans-unit.target: Let your fork know you created the local working branch:

trans-unit.source: Create your new article or make changes to an existing article.
trans-unit.target: Create your new article or make changes to an existing article.

trans-unit.source: Use Windows Explorer to open and create new markdown files, and use Atom (http://atom.io) as your markdown editor.
trans-unit.target: Use Windows Explorer to open and create new markdown files, and use Atom (http://atom.io) as your markdown editor.

trans-unit.source: After you created or modified your article and images, go to the next step.
trans-unit.target: After you created or modified your article and images, go to the next step.

trans-unit.source: Add and commit the changes you made:
trans-unit.target: Add and commit the changes you made:

trans-unit.source: Or, to add only the specific files you modified:
trans-unit.target: Or, to add only the specific files you modified:

trans-unit.source: Update your local working branch with changes from upstream:
trans-unit.target: Update your local working branch with changes from upstream:

trans-unit.source: Push the changes to your fork on GitHub:
trans-unit.target: Push the changes to your fork on GitHub:

trans-unit.source: When you are ready to submit your content to the upstream master branch for staging, validation, and/or publishing, in the GitHub UI, create a pull request from your fork to the master branch.
trans-unit.target: When you are ready to submit your content to the upstream master branch for staging, validation, and/or publishing, in the GitHub UI, create a pull request from your fork to the master branch.

trans-unit.source: The pull request acceptor reviews your pull request, provides feedback, and/or accepts your pull request.
trans-unit.target: The pull request acceptor reviews your pull request, provides feedback, and/or accepts your pull request.

trans-unit.source: Verify your published article or changes at
trans-unit.target: Verify your published article or changes at

trans-unit.source: http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/*name-of-your-article-without-the-MD-extension*
trans-unit.target: http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/*name-of-your-article-without-the-MD-extension*

trans-unit.source: Notes:
trans-unit.target: Notes:

trans-unit.source: At this time, technical articles are published once daily around 10 AM Pacific Standard Time (PST), Monday-Friday.
trans-unit.target: At this time, technical articles are published once daily around 10 AM Pacific Standard Time (PST), Monday-Friday.

trans-unit.source: Remember, your pull request has to be accepted before changes are included in the next scheduled publishing run.
trans-unit.target: Remember, your pull request has to be accepted before changes are included in the next scheduled publishing run.

trans-unit.source: If you are an employee working in the private repository, all pull requests are subject to validation rules that need to be addressed before the pull request can be accepted.
trans-unit.target: If you are an employee working in the private repository, all pull requests are subject to validation rules that need to be addressed before the pull request can be accepted.

trans-unit.source: In the private repo, the changes you submit are automatically staged, and a staging link is written to the pull request.
trans-unit.target: In the private repo, the changes you submit are automatically staged, and a staging link is written to the pull request.

trans-unit.source: Please review your staged content and sign off in the pull request comments to indicate the changes are ready to be pushed live.
trans-unit.target: Please review your staged content and sign off in the pull request comments to indicate the changes are ready to be pushed live.

trans-unit.source: If you don't want the pull request to be accepted - if you are just staging the changes - add that note to the pull request.
trans-unit.target: If you don't want the pull request to be accepted - if you are just staging the changes - add that note to the pull request.

trans-unit.source: Working with release branches
trans-unit.target: Working with release branches

trans-unit.source: When you are working with a release branch, the best way to create a local working branch from the release branch is to use this command syntax:
trans-unit.target: When you are working with a release branch, the best way to create a local working branch from the release branch is to use this command syntax:

trans-unit.source: This creates the local branch directly from the upstream branch, avoiding any local merging.
trans-unit.target: This creates the local branch directly from the upstream branch, avoiding any local merging.
